message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history of smoking and IV heroin use suggests a higher risk of systemic hypertension, which can lead to left ventricular hypertrophy. The ECG findings of left axis deviation and prominent QRS voltage are also commonly seen in patients with systemic hypertension. Aortic regurgitation and mitral stenosis typically cause eccentric left ventricular hypertrophy, while pulmonary hypertension would lead to right ventricular hypertrophy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's smoking and drug use suggest that he may have hypertension. The ECG findings of prominent QRS voltage and left axis deviation, along with the echocardiogram findings of mild concentric left ventricular hypertrophy, are consistent with systemic hypertension. None of the other options are consistent with these findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Left ventricular hypertrophy is a common finding in patients with systemic hypertension, but not in patients with aortic regurgitation, mitral stenosis, or pulmonary hypertension. The patient’s smoking and IV heroin use may also contribute to the development of hypertension and left ventricular hypertrophy.

The prominent QRS voltage and left axis deviation seen on ECG can also be consistent with this diagnosis. The other options are less likely given the patient’s clinical history and exam.

Prominent QRS voltage and left axis deviation on ECG also suggest left ventricular hypertrophy. There is no indication of valvular disease or pulmonary hypertension.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s smoking and IV drug use put him at high risk for developing systemic hypertension, which can lead to left ventricular hypertrophy. Aortic regurgitation and mitral stenosis would be seen on echocardiography. Pulmonary hypertension would cause right ventricular hypertrophy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s smoking and IV heroin use suggest a history of substance abuse, which can lead to systemic hypertension, causing left ventricular hypertrophy as found on the echocardiogram. The ECG findings confirm left axis deviation, which can also be seen in systemic hypertension. The other options are less likely to cause these findings. Aortic regurgitation can cause left ventricular hypertrophy but is unlikely in this patient’s age group without other risk factors. Mitral stenosis usually presents with left atrial hypertrophy and signs of right heart failure. Pulmonary hypertension can cause right ventricular hypertrophy, but the echocardiogram shows hypertrophy only on the left side.
